This course will examine historical and contemporary martyrdom in various religious and political contexts.

RCS353.title: RCS353 - War and Peace in Christianity
RCS353.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS353.description: Christians have engaged in complex debates about the ethics of war and peace. Students will critically examine a range of beliefs and practices within Christianity, especially pacifism and nonviolent resistance, just war, and realism. They will examine how diverse Christian beliefs developed in relation to different historical and cultural contexts, and assess the implications of various approaches. Students will encounter practitioners who have sought to put into action various Christian ethical theories and spiritualities in response to armed conflict.

RCS354.title: RCS354 - Shapers of Roman Catholicism
RCS354.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS354.description: An examination of influential Christian thinkers - both historical and contemporary - who have played a critical role in shaping Roman Catholic thought and practice. Issues include debates on the nature of God, sin and redemption, authority in the Church, and perspectives on gender and sexuality.

RCS355.title: RCS355 - Christianity, Gender, and Justice
RCS355.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS355.description: New thinking about the nature and meaning of gender in Christianity has challenged traditional teaching and practices at every level. This course will explore how writers concerned with gender and justice have disrupted traditional disciplines of theology and spirituality and introduced innovations into Church thinking and practice.

RCS357.title: RCS357 - The Church's Song
RCS357.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS357.description: This course examines the origins of the music sung by the Christian church and its development up to the present. The course considers the Church's Song as theological, poetic, musical, cultural, and spiritual expression, and the use of songs in a variety of worship settings. Students will practice methods of song analysis, assess musical meaning, value and effects in various cultural contexts, and reflect on written and oral transmission of music.

RCS358.title: RCS358 - Worship and its Music
RCS358.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS358.description: The nature of worship and the role of music within worship in historical, theological, and cultural perspectives. Field trips to services of various traditions.

RCS361.title: RCS361 - Anthropology of Religion
RCS361.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS361.description: This course examines how religion has been studied as an object of anthropological inquiry. Topics may include ritual, magic, witchcraft, symbolism, cosmology, the relation between beliefs and practices, as well as the mutual influences of religion, politics, nationalism, and socioeconomic change.

RCS364.title: RCS364 - Jewish Humour: Laughing Your Way Through History
RCS364.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS364.description: Jewish comedians have dominated humour in North America from Groucho Marx to Jerry Seinfeld, Sarah Silverman, Amy Schumer, and Seth Rogen. Studying Jewish humour is critical for understanding the development of Judaism, Jewish identity, immigrant experience, and response to persecution.

RCS377.title: RCS377 - Religion in Science Fiction Films and Television
RCS377.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS377.description: This course examines how religion, religious themes, and the religious imagination are explored in and through science fiction film and television. Topics include the use of science fiction to discuss questions of transcendence, humanity, and divinity, as well as the challenge of extraterrestrial and artificial lifeforms.

RCS380.title: RCS380 - Religion and Peacebuilding
RCS380.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS380.description: This course investigates the roles of religion and spirituality in peacemaking, exploring both obstacles and opportunities facing religious peace builders. Cases involving representatives of major world religions (Christianity, Islam, Judaism, Hinduism, and Buddhism) will provide a basis for comparing practices of faith-based advocacy for social justice, reconciliation, and coexistence.

RCS383.title: RCS383 - Justice, Peace, and Development
RCS383.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS383.description: An examination of communities, movements, and theologies which express a Christian hope for justice, peace, and development in the encounter with injustice, oppression, and poverty.

RCS387.title: RCS387 - Aging and the Spiritual Life
RCS387.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS387.description: Engaging experience, theory, and reflection, this course explores spirituality as a central aspect of growth and development in later life. This course draws on perspectives from various faith and humanistic traditions. Topics include religious beliefs and spiritual concerns later in life, a spirituality of aging, providing spiritual care to persons in later life, spirituality and dementia, and death and dying.

RCS398.title: RCS398 - Directed Readings in Special Subjects
RCS398.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS398.description: Readings in selected topics chosen in discussion with instructor.

RCS420R.title: RCS420R - Critical Encounter with Human Nature
RCS420R.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS420R.description: This course explores issues fundamental to human nature and related theoretical explanations. The approach is interdisciplinary and intercultural/interreligious. Through various assignments, students will gain an understanding of their own perspectives on human nature, the questions of human "being" that those raise, and the purpose of human existence.

RCS450.title: RCS450 - Reading and Interpreting the Qur'an (in translation)
RCS450.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS450.description: This course serves as a comprehensive introduction to the sacred text of Islam. Students engage the Qur'an using a wide array of interpretive approaches, from traditional forms of exegesis to new trends in the academic study of the Qur'an.

RCS462.title: RCS462 - Religion and Spirituality in the Social and Legal World
RCS462.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS462.description: This course examines key substantive, theoretical, and methodological issues in the field of sociology of religion. Students will critically analyze high-profile media and legal cases surrounding the role of religion, spirituality, and secularity in Canadian society. Students will also further their knowledge by completing their own projects in this thematic area, developing both their research and written skills.

RCS491.title: RCS491 - Special Topics
RCS491.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS491.description: Consult the department for special topics.

RCS495.title: RCS495 - Study Term Abroad
RCS495.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS495.description: Consult the department for current offerings.

RCS498.title: RCS498 - Directed Readings in Special Subjects
RCS498.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS498.description: Readings in selected topics chosen in discussion with instructor.

RCS499.title: RCS499 - Senior Seminar
RCS499.subject: Religion, Culture, and Spirituality (RCS)
RCS499.description: This seminar examines contemporary methods and theories in the study of religion and how they may be used to address specific themes in religious studies.

RUSS101.title: RUSS101 - Elementary Russian 1
RUSS101.subject: Russian (RUSS)
RUSS101.description: This course aims to bring Russian language, culture, and everyday life into the classroom. Students with little or no prior knowledge are introduced to the structure of Russian and develop their listening/comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Classes are communicative and emphasize interaction in Russian.

REES120.title: REES120 - Once Upon a Fairy Tale: Fairy Tales, Then and Now
REES120.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES120.description: This course studies fairy tales in the broader context of the history of childhood and practices of education and socialization. The course will focus on fairy tales of German and Russian origins and consider their interpretations and reinterpretations in different historical periods. This may include figures from the Brothers Grimm and Alexander Afanasyev, such as Snow White, Sleeping Beauty, Red Riding Hood, and the Firebird.

REES180.title: REES180 - German and Russian Literary Masterpieces
REES180.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES180.description: An examination of major Russian and German literary works that have influenced world literature.

REES230.title: REES230 - The Devil
REES230.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES230.description: An examination of the Devil and demonic figures in the Russian and Slavic cultural traditions based on examples drawn from literature, music, the visual arts, and film. Connections to a larger Western cultural context are also explored.

REES240.title: REES240 - Mediterranean Cultures in their European Context
REES240.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES240.description: An introduction to modern eastern Mediterranean societies, focusing primarily on Croatia and its neighbours, and examining the historical, cultural, economic, and socio-political interconnectedness of these societies, situated at a crossroads of both East/West and North/South communication and commerce. Students will discuss different perspectives on issues such as cultural diversity, gender relations, migration, and the place of the Mediterranean in the human imagination, developing critical thinking skills by analyzing relevant readings and engaging in independent research.

REES260.title: REES260 - Special Topics
REES260.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES260.description: Selected topics in Russian and East European studies chosen by the instructor in consultation with the department. The topics chosen introduce students to important issues in eastern European culture.

REES261.title: REES261 - Understanding Conversation
REES261.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES261.description: This course examines the connection between conversation and cultural identities. Looking at conversation means looking at language structures and language choice but also at gesture, gaze, laughter, and emojis. We will analyze everyday conversation as well as interaction in digital contexts, with the goal of discovering how linguistic and multimodal choices convey and construct who we are.

REES262.title: REES262 - Multilingualism
REES262.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES262.description: This course examines the concept of multilingualism in society from a social, cultural, and linguistic perspective. It covers topics such as multilingualism in the media, endangered languages, language and identities, language maintenance and loss, language planning and politics, and multilingual education.

REES272.title: REES272 - Russian Thought and Culture
REES272.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES272.description: An introduction to Russian culture from the 19th century to the present day through the close study of selected works of literature, art, film, and music.

REES364.title: REES364 - German and Russian Film Pioneers
REES364.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES364.description: An examination of early German and Russian cinema, and the way these two film industries influenced each other. Influential theories of film from the period will also be studied.

REES385.title: REES385 - Culture Behind the Iron Curtain
REES385.subject: Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES)
REES385.description: An examination of the culture of the Soviet Union, the German Democratic Republic, and other states that experimented with socialism in the 20th century. Representations of Marxist-Leninist and Stalinist ideologies in literature, cinema, and the arts; the role of the state in directing cultural expression; and resistance to totalitarian control of culture are examined. Western representations of the Cold War are also studied.

SCI200.title: SCI200 - Energy - Its Development, Use, and Issues
SCI200.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI200.description: A survey course which deals with energy resources, their conversion into energy products and their use in today's industrial societies. In light of the Energy Technology Perspectives (ETP) Model, energy supply demand, and conservation constraints, the use of non-renewable fossil and nuclear fuels, biofuels and other renewable fuels (wind, hydraulic, solar) will be reviewed and technical and social issues arising from their use explored. This course should prepare students to analyze and deal with the many contradictory energy usage claims and decide for themselves the best course of energy use.

SCI201.title: SCI201 - Global Warming and Climate Change
SCI201.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI201.description: This course will survey a broad spectrum of topics relating to global climate change, with an emphasis on the scientific approaches to address this issue. Topics covered will include natural and anthropogenic causes of climate change, monitoring methods, current and low emission alternatives of energy production. The scientific, economic, public and political aspects of implementation of carbon capture and storage technology and other geo-engineering options to mitigate climate change will also be discussed.

SCI206.title: SCI206 - The Physics of How Things Work
SCI206.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI206.description: A practical introduction to everyday technology, this course will look at the physics behind common devices used in consumer products and industry. Examples include air conditioners, microwave ovens, household wiring, nuclear reactors, and medical imaging.

SCI207.title: SCI207 - Physics, the Universe, and Everything
SCI207.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI207.description: How does the universe work? How can it even exist? What is the ultimate nature of reality? This course explores big picture questions that connect humanity to the nature of the physical world. Beginning with introduction to Einstein's ideas and the quantum nature of the universe, this course considers how physicists tackle some of the mysteries (e.g., existence itself) and challenges (e.g., the world's energy problem) in science today.

SCI211.title: SCI211 - Traditional Medicines Land-Based Field Course
SCI211.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI211.description: A four-day land-based field course. Students will engage with Indigenous instructors and community members to learn traditional medicine knowledges. Delivery will be blended with online preparatory lectures. Land-based learning, and teaching circles with Indigenous Knowledge Holders.

SCI227.title: SCI227 - Chemistry in Society: Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow
SCI227.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI227.description: This course surveys the impact of chemistry on our lives and explores the role of chemists and the chemical sciences in addressing the past and especially the present and future needs of society. Topics will vary from year to year, but will be drawn from the following critical areas: food, energy, materials, health, and the environment.

SCI230.title: SCI230 - Global Aspects of Technological Innovation and Entrepreneurship
SCI230.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI230.description: This concentrated 18-day block course features a combination of academic study, group work, and field trips in Southern Ontario and Israel. The course focuses on cultural exchange and experiential learning on technological scientific innovation and entrepreneurship where students will interact with companies with a global impact. Students will examine different approaches to transforming scientific innovations into useful products.

SCI238.title: SCI238 - Introductory Astronomy
SCI238.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI238.description: A survey course in astronomy. The solar system, the Sun and planets, stars, the Milky Way, galaxies, and cosmology.

SCI250.title: SCI250 - Environmental Geology
SCI250.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI250.description: An introduction to geological concepts; the influence of geological factors on the natural environment; Earth processes and natural hazards; Earth resources, including water, energy and mineral resources; waste disposal and pollution; global climatic and environmental change.

SCI252.title: SCI252 - Quantum Mechanics for Everyone
SCI252.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI252.description: Quantum mechanics is driving a technological revolution. This course offers an introduction to the basic concepts of quantum mechanics from a historical and philosophical perspective. The course will supply the background needed to understand the controversies surrounding the interpretation of quantum mechanics as well as the principles behind the cutting-edge research being carried out at the Perimeter Institute and the University of Waterloo.

SCI266.title: SCI266 - Ancient Science
SCI266.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI266.description: The ancient Greeks developed scientific theories that were influential for over a thousand years. Their worldview was different from ours, but they sought to explain some of the same phenomena that we grapple with today. In this course, we will study ancient Greek theories and methodologies in the sciences, which may include physics, astronomy, mathematics, meteorology, cosmology, astrology, and geography.

SCI267.title: SCI267 - Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
SCI267.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI267.description: This course considers fundamental questions concerning the nature of science. Consideration is given to such topics as scientific methodology, scientific revolutions, natural laws, and the debate about whether scientific theories represent reality, or just our perceptions of reality.

SCI280.title: SCI280 - Science Field Course
SCI280.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI280.description: This special topic field course of broad interests will provide students with hands-on field experience, a connection with experts, and, alternative learning modes, relevant to all students in the Faculty of Science.

SCI281.title: SCI281 - Science Field Course
SCI281.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI281.description: This special topic field course of broad interests will provide students with hands-on field experience, a connection with experts, and, alternative learning modes, relevant to all students in the Faculty of Science.

SCI300.title: SCI300 - Special Topics in Science
SCI300.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI300.description: These special topics courses will cover material relevant to all students in the Faculty of Science. Course content is not specific to an individual program.

SCI301.title: SCI301 - Special Topics in Science
SCI301.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI301.description: These special topics courses will cover material relevant to all students in the Faculty of Science. Course content is not specific to an individual program.

SCI395.title: SCI395 - Science Study Abroad Program
SCI395.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI395.description: Waterloo students studying abroad for academic transfer credits under a Science Exchange Program during the Fall term.

SCI396.title: SCI396 - Science Study Abroad Program
SCI396.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI396.description: Waterloo students studying abroad for academic transfer credits under a Science Exchange Program during the Winter term.

SCI397.title: SCI397 - Science Study Abroad Program
SCI397.subject: Science (SCI)
SCI397.description: Waterloo students studying abroad for academic transfer credits under a Science Exchange Program during the Spring term.

SCBUS122.title: SCBUS122 - Management of Business Organizations
SCBUS122.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS122.description: This course uses case studies, project management, team/group dynamics, and strategies to explore the essential parameters that comprise the management of business organizations: planning, organization, leadership, control, and ethics. The course considers the importance of diversity/globalization, human resource management, a comparison of traditional and entrepreneurial leadership, and management as well as business ethics.

SCBUS123.title: SCBUS123 - Workshop 1: Science and Business
SCBUS123.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS123.description: This workshop addresses concepts of technology development and related marketing aspects that undertake an analysis of a firm's existence, its physical and/or social media presence, and customer feedback. Students work in collaborative teams to tackle case studies and class exercises. A major deliverable is the development of a team marketing plan, where market segments are identified based on revenue and market potential. This involves conducting a PESTLE and SWOT analysis, market planning, information retrieval strategies, scientific business forecasting, competitive intelligence, and product development. Results are presented orally and in writing.

SCBUS223.title: SCBUS223 - Workshop 2: Strategies Behind Technological Innovation
SCBUS223.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS223.description: This workshop is organized as a strategic management process, focusing on the management of technology, innovation, research and development in scientific team-based settings. Students working in groups analyze real business ventures, their launch, and growth, synthesizing major field research to develop a term deliverable in the form of a company report and final project presentation. Students engage in experiential learning involving theory, case studies, scientific team debates, and critical reasoning.

SCBUS225.title: SCBUS225 - Organizational Behaviour in Scientific and Technical Workplaces
SCBUS225.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS225.description: This workshop uses case studies, lectures, and discussions to explore a basic understanding of how organizations work, and how people interact within organizations in order to achieve ethical human, organizational, and social objectives. This course considers organizational structure and models, ethics, organizational theory, organizational culture, motivation, diversity, negotiation, communication, leadership, and management, and how these principles are applied in start ups or scientific and technical environments. There is a major project that focuses on an aspect of organizational behaviour in a scientific or technical firm or application, and is presented in writing and orally.

SCBUS323.title: SCBUS323 - Workshop 3: Technology Development
SCBUS323.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS323.description: A senior honours project focusing on technology innovation, assessment of the current utility of a technology, scale-up of the technology, projected return on investment and hurdles (production, regulatory, market competition, intellectual property protection). The major class project focuses on the development of a business plan for a product that could be commercialized. Applications, implications, cost benefit analysis, feasibility, etc. are included.

SCBUS423.title: SCBUS423 - Workshop 4: Strategic Management of Science and Business
SCBUS423.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS423.description: Current real-world issues and problems in the strategic management of start-ups and scientific/technology companies are addressed, based on the use of publicly available information including research findings. Working in groups, students will address the topics to be pursued, including both scientific and business/economic aspects. Assignments result in a written strategic plan, which is formally presented to the class.

SCBUS424.title: SCBUS424 - Workshop 5: Special Topics in Science and Business
SCBUS424.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS424.description: This capstone-project workshop addresses the formulation of firm-wide strategic plans (e.g., business cases, marketing plans, strategic plans) for science and technology based start-ups and traditional firms. It provides a framework for developing and implementing business strategies and the related documentation that fits a firm's environment, human resources, markets, managerial styles and organization. This course involves significant group work under the supervision of a Science and Business instructor. A written report and seminar presentation are required. A special capstone project is also required.

SCBUS425.title: SCBUS425 - Workshop 6: Challenges in Globalizing Science and Technology
SCBUS425.subject: Science and Business (SCBUS)
SCBUS425.description: This workshop addresses the implications for Canadian science and technology based firms of competing in the global competitive environment.

SRF101.title: SRF101 - Introduction to Sexualities, Relationships, and Families
SRF101.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF101.description: This course introduces students to the study of sexualities, relationships, and families from an interdisciplinary perspective. Students will develop a greater awareness and understanding about healthy relationships that are inclusive of diversity. This course addresses relational violence.

SRF111.title: SRF111 - Women, Sex, Marriage, and Family Traditions in Italy
SRF111.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF111.description: This course explores the contributions of Italian women artists, writers, and intellectuals from the Medieval through the Renaissance and Baroque periods. Students will learn about sexual culture, the institution of marriage, the role of the family, and gender roles as portrayed in the works of Italian women from these periods. Students will also assess and compare ideas across these time periods and become aware of the implications of studying these topics in the context of nationality.

SRF112.title: SRF112 - Women, Sexual Identities, and Relationships in Italy
SRF112.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF112.description: This course explores the contributions of Italian women artists, writers, and intellectuals from the Enlightenment until contemporary times. Students will assess critically key themes in Italian womens expression of sexual identities, the nature of relationships, and the influence of family ties as portrayed in Italian literature, art, and philosophy from these periods. Students will become familiar with concepts that mark the development of the Italian female imagery from the 18th to the 21st century.

SRF200.title: SRF200 - Special Topics in Sexualities, Relationships, or Families
SRF200.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF200.description: In this course students will engage with diverse materials and approaches in the study of topics on sexualities, relationships, and/or families.

SRF204.title: SRF204 - Introduction to Human Sexualities
SRF204.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF204.description: This course provides an interdisciplinary overview of theories and research on human sexualities. Students will explore and deepen their understanding of human sexuality as a complex, diverse, multidimensional, and multilevel domain of life. Students will also learn to critically reflect upon their own understandings and commonly held discourses on human sexualities.

SRF205.title: SRF205 - The Dark Side of Sex and Sexualities
SRF205.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF205.description: Students will engage in the theoretical and empirical examinations of contentious and controversial topics associated with human sexuality. Students may critically examine topics such as sex work, pornography, sexual violence and abuse, incest, compulsive sexual behaviour, and paraphilias.

SRF207.title: SRF207 - Parent and Child Relations
SRF207.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF207.description: This course introduces students to parent-child/caregiver-child relationships from a broad interdisciplinary perspective over the lifespan. Students will critically examine topics such as the transition to parenthood, parenting practices and their intersection with child/adult development, social and cultural influences on families with children, gender variance/fluidity and family relationships, and family life challenges.

SRF208.title: SRF208 - Introduction to Systemic Therapies and Anti-Oppressive Practices
SRF208.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF208.description: In this course students are introduced to an overview of systemic theoretical and therapeutic practices in relational and sex therapy that apply social justice, anti-oppressive, and inclusionary practices. Students will consider and critically analyze the intersections of social locations such as class, culture, ability/disability, gender, and race within various social contexts. Student learning culminates in the design and presentation of an interactive exhibit project.

SRF211.title: SRF211 - Dynamics of Dating
SRF211.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF211.description: This course facilitates students knowledge and understanding of the dynamics of intimate relationships in the context of the modern, Western social construct of dating. Topics explored may include digital communications and technology, hook-up culture, long-distance relationships, online dating, polyamorous relationships, and the role of pop culture in dating attitudes and beliefs. Through a variety of assignments and assessments, students will develop a greater awareness of diverse dating processes and structures and critically reflect on their own perspectives about dating.

SRF212.title: SRF212 - Sexualities and Relationships in Mid/Later Life
SRF212.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF212.description: This course will introduce students to the complexities, tribulations, and joys of navigating sexuality and relationships as humans age. Topics may include physical/biological changes, navigating dementia, youth-focused culture, relationship dissolution and relationship anew, death of partners, family and friends, the menopausal transition, and ageism. Through this course students will increase their understanding of how sexuality and relationships change, grow, and remain the same as people age, and how age intersects with such things as race, gender, sexual orientation, ability/disability, culture, socioeconomic status, and societal expectations, allowing reflection on their own bias, experience, and aging scripts.

SRF213.title: SRF213 - Sexual Health and Well-Being
SRF213.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF213.description: This course provides students an interdisciplinary overview of sexual health and well-being from a theoretical and practical framework. It unpacks the potential role individuals, communities, and institutions have in defining, preventing, and developing sexual health. Topics may include menstrual equity, STIs and safer sex, chronic and long-term illnesses, 2SLGBTQIA+ sexual health, birth control, and pleasure as health. Students will learn to recognize and challenge potentially harmful normative scripts regarding sexual health and well-being, as well as be given the opportunity to reflect on their own experiences, education, beliefs, and biases in relation to the various dimensions of sexual health.

SRF214.title: SRF214 - Constructing Erotics
SRF214.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF214.description: This course examines the social construction of the erotic, in particular how culture, politics, religion, literature, economics, medicine, or technology interact to regulate the definition and performance of sexuality across cultures. Topics may include the sexual body (e.g., beauty and desire), the regulation of sex (e.g., taboos, laws, religion), and other cultural constructions of sexuality (e.g., sexual education).

SRF215.title: SRF215 - Sexuality and Popular Culture
SRF215.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF215.description: Students will examine and explore how sex and sexualities are depicted in, shaped by, and contested in popular culture. Students will be introduced to theories in the study of popular culture and sexualities through a range of historical and contemporary texts and practices. Students will be encouraged to recognize and critically reflect on the extent to which human sexualities are complex, intersectional, and multidimensional domains of everyday life as they appear in popular culture forms and how the limits of those forms may shape social understanding of human sexuality.

SRF216.title: SRF216 - Sexual Pleasure
SRF216.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF216.description: This course provides a theoretical and empirical examination of the pleasurable and recreational aspects of human sexuality. Students will learn about psychological, interpersonal, and sociocultural processes related to discourses, practices, and experiences of sexual pleasure. Students will also learn to critically reflect on various popular and scientific perspectives related to sexual pleasure. Topics may include sexual satisfaction, optimal sexuality, passion, fantasies, eroticism, embodiment, sexual devices and technologies, sexual techniques, BDSM, and sexual role-playing.

SRF218.title: SRF218 - Sexual Health and Well-Being in Comics
SRF218.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF218.description: This course will present a concentrated history of the major trends and patterns within the representation of human sexuality and sexual health in 20th- and 21st-century comics art. Students will be introduced to the unique and powerful role that comics have played in representing sexuality and sexual well-being through exposure to various artists and scholars on the subject. Students will explore key concepts through close readings of relevant texts, and through the application of key theoretical materials, modeling the kind of analytical work that students will then produce themselves in both discussion and written assignments.

SRF220.title: SRF220 - Introduction to Research Methods
SRF220.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF220.description: This course provides an interdisciplinary overview of the philosophical, theoretical, and practical foundations of research methods used in the social sciences and humanities to study sexualities, relationships, and families. Students will learn about both qualitative and quantitative methods, the role of theory in research, and ethical issues pertaining to research. Students will acquire foundational skills for constructing research proposals and becoming critical consumers of research.

SRF230.title: SRF230 - Introduction to Statistics
SRF230.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF230.description: This course introduces the basics of statistics commonly used in the social sciences for the study of sexualities, relationships, and families. Students will learn about the fundamental components, logic, execution, current debates, and best practices related to basic descriptive and inferential statistics. They will learn to read, understand, and interpret statistics, as well as become critical consumers of statistics. They will develop the skills to conduct quantitative analyses using statistical software and write a quantitative research paper.

SRF241.title: SRF241 - Caregiving, Illness, and Relationships
SRF241.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF241.description: In the typical health care model most of the attention is focused on the patient and their well-being, often ignoring the health, financial, and emotional impact on those who provide unpaid informal care and support - family and friends. Through the reading of memoirs, students with an interest in aging, health care, and the therapeutic professions will grapple with the profound impact that caregiving during illness has on carers and relationships across the spectrum - from young carers, to intimate partners, to adult children caring for aging parents, and beyond. Discussions will be grounded in the social, legal, and policy contexts.

SRF250.title: SRF250 - Family Policy and the Law
SRF250.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF250.description: There is a persistent tension in our society about where the responsibility for children lies: with the family or the society. This course examines various topics in Canadian social and family policy that affect children's development and family well-being. Topics may include the legislative provisions in areas such as parenting supports, income security, family law, youth justice, caregiving, and the distinct framework for Indigenous families. Students will use foundational concepts and theories to examine the strengths and limitations of policy to address the needs of families.

SRF301.title: SRF301 - Communication and Counselling Skills
SRF301.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF301.description: This course introduces students to the theories and methods of communication as applied to processes of individual, relational, and family consultation and counselling. Through functional experiential activities and written reflections, students will apply course concepts and examine their own thoughts, beliefs, and positionings as they develop and strengthen their communication skills. Through application-based course assignments, students will deepen their understanding of intersectional, anti-oppressive frameworks and apply them to active listening and intentional interviewing across human service contexts and relationships.

SRF304.title: SRF304 - Human Sexuality in Relationships
SRF304.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF304.description: This course examines the development and experience of sexuality in a relational context from infancy to old age. Emphasis will be placed on sexual interaction and communication in adult relationships, but the effects of relationships on sexual experiences during infancy, childhood, adolescence, and old age may also be examined.

SRF305.title: SRF305 - Social Issues and Controversies in Human Sexuality
SRF305.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF305.description: This course will provide students with an examination of selected issues and controversies in human sexualities, providing an interdisciplinary, learner-centered perspective drawing on family studies, psychology, sociology, feminism, critical scholarship, and more. Through this course students will increase their understanding of the historical, biological, social, political, religious, and cultural forces that shape human sexualities across the lifespan. Students will practice critical thinking and self-reflective skills in the analysis of issues and controversies in the field of human sexuality.

SRF306.title: SRF306 - Intimate Relationships
SRF306.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF306.description: Students will examine theories and research to understand the dynamics of interpersonal and intimate relationships. Through examining topics such as attraction, commitment, love, trust, communication, and dissolution, students will expand and deepen their understanding of various theoretical and empirical perspectives about relationships. Students will continue to develop and build on their oral and written capacities to bridge the gap between research, theory, and praxis in understanding and articulating the implications for intimate relationships.

SRF307.title: SRF307 - Conflict in Close Relationships
SRF307.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF307.description: Families and close relationships are among the most important and valued human experiences, but they can also be the source of much conflict and pain. Students will build their knowledge as they consider the role that conflict plays in close relationships, with a focus on topics such as family of origin, emotions, power, third-party interventions, breakdown of relationships, conflict styles, and conflict resolution.

SRF308.title: SRF308 - Relational Therapy
SRF308.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF308.description: In this course students will learn and engage with modern and postmodern therapeutic approaches to working clinically within relational contexts (e.g., family, romantic, other relationship configurations). This course emphasizes systemic thinking, cultural sensitivity, social justice, and anti-oppressive practices in therapeutic settings. Through experiential assignments/activities students will apply theory to practice and explore ethical implications associated with doing clinical work.

SRF309.title: SRF309 - Sex Therapy
SRF309.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF309.description: This course will give students the opportunity to critically integrate various therapeutic approaches and clinical issues when working with sexuality-related concerns. Research and theoretical issues in the field of sex therapy will be discussed and applied to clinical contexts. The applied focus enables students to connect clinical theory and ethical issues to practice.

SRF310.title: SRF310 - Sexual and Relational Ethics
SRF310.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF310.description: This course provides an interdisciplinary overview of ethics and its applications to sexualities and relationships. Students will learn about basic ethical theories, concepts, issues, and reasoning skills. Students will learn how to apply ethical principles to critically analyze difficult life situations and controversial social issues. Students will learn to engage in and cultivate constructive arguments and discussions on ethical matters.

SRF317.title: SRF317 - History of Sexuality: The Pre-Modern Period
SRF317.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF317.description: This course introduces students to the history of Western sexuality, beginning with the ancient world and focusing primarily on the Middle Ages and the transition to modernity.

SRF318.title: SRF318 - History of Sexuality: The Modern Period
SRF318.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF318.description: This seminar introduces students to the history of sexuality. The course focuses on the 19th and 20th centuries.

SRF350.title: SRF350 - Love and the Law
SRF350.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF350.description: Relationship breakdown is a social phenomenon that can have legal consequences. This course provides students with a socio-legal foundation in current family law. Topics may include the court system, the litigation process, property division, spousal and child support, child co-parenting, child protection, high conflict families, and alternative dispute resolution processes. Students will learn about the strengths and limitation of the law to address relationship breakdown and develop transferable skills for careers in policy, social work, mediation, family justice, education, and community service organizations.

SRF365.title: SRF365 - Special Topics in Human Sexualities
SRF365.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF365.description: A specialized course in topics related to human sexualities. Topics cover the application of theory and research in any area related to human sexualities.

SRF366.title: SRF366 - Special Topics in Relationships and Families
SRF366.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF366.description: A specialized course in topics that cover the application of theory and research in any area related to relationships and families.

SRF400.title: SRF400 - Capstone Seminar
SRF400.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF400.description: This seminar, taken in students final Sexualities, Relationships, and Families winter term, invites students to integrate their knowledge in the domains of sexualities, relationships, and families and make connections across academic, experiential, and personal learning throughout their undergraduate education. Students will critically reflect on their learning experiences and how they will apply these to their future endeavours. Students will process their learning through a variety of possible methods, such as reflective writing, presentations, and contributions to a capstone class project.

SRF404.title: SRF404 - Independent Study in Sexualities, Relationships, and/or Families
SRF404.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF404.description: Students will develop and write an in-depth study proposal and/or literature review based on empirical research and an extensive reading of a topic in the area of sexualities, relationships, and/or families. Students are generally expected to give a presentation on their project. The project must be approved by the academic supervisor of the course prior to enrolment.

SRF490.title: SRF490 - Practicum and Professional Ethics
SRF490.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF490.description: In this course students undertake an unpaid apprenticeship in a human services setting. This practicum field placement is complemented by regular seminar meetings to support and assess student learning. The practicum field placement requires 15 hours per week for eight months (fall and winter terms). Through the practicum experience students learn to integrate and apply their undergraduate Sexualities, Relationships, and Families education and bridge theory, research, and praxis.

SRF491.title: SRF491 - Practicum and Applied Theory
SRF491.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF491.description: This course is the continuation of the SRF490 practicum field placement along with weekly seminar meetings that focus on integration of theory, practice, and praxis.

SRF494.title: SRF494 - Seminar in Sexualities
SRF494.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF494.description: This senior level seminar allows students to further explore, deepen, and integrate their knowledge in the study of sexualities. Students will engage in critical analysis through discussions, presentations, and/or written assignments. Topics reflect current issues from a theoretical and research perspective.

SRF496.title: SRF496 - Seminar in the Study of Families
SRF496.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF496.description: This senior level seminar allows students to further explore, deepen, and integrate their knowledge in the domains of relationships and families. Students will engage in critical analysis through discussions, presentations, and written assignments. Topics reflect current issues from a theoretical and research perspective.

SRF499A.title: SRF499A - Thesis - Part 1
SRF499A.subject: Sexualities, Relationships, and Families (SRF)
SRF499A.description: Under supervision of a faculty member, students normally will review literature, design a study, present a research proposal, analyze data, write a scholarly research paper, and deliver an oral presentation based on the paper (e.g., at the SRF Research Symposium).

SDS131R.title: SDS131R - Political Ideologies and Social Development
SDS131R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS131R.description: This course introduces major political ideologies, their influence in political institutions and public discourse, and their impact on contemporary Canadian social policy and social development.

SDS150R.title: SDS150R - Lifespan Processes
SDS150R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS150R.description: This course is an introduction to human development that spans conception to death. It provides an overview of events which occur throughout the lifespan and considers how biological, psychological, and social factors may impact healthy development.

SDS205R.title: SDS205R - History of Education in Canada
SDS205R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS205R.description: This course considers the development of education as an institution within Canadian society and provides an understanding of significant educational issues and policies from a historical perspective.

SDS210R.title: SDS210R - Children's Rights in Canada
SDS210R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS210R.description: This course examines children's rights from a moral and comparative legal perspective. Students explore the welfare and developmental interests of children; the corresponding duties of parents, custodians, educators, and social workers; and the nature and scope of public educational authority in the common law jurisdictions of Canada.

SDS215R.title: SDS215R - Education and Social Development from a Global Perspective
SDS215R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS215R.description: This course explores education and social development from a critical global perspective. Students learn the connections between educational practices and global conditions by focusing on themes such as citizenship, human rights, peace, and environment.

SDS220R.title: SDS220R - Changing Concepts of Childhood
SDS220R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS220R.description: Childhood has changed as a social and cultural concept. This course will trace these changes, examining sociological, psychological, cross-cultural, historical and political factors. Art and literature will also be used to reflect attitudes about childhood.

SDS231R.title: SDS231R - Introduction to Social Policy Processes
SDS231R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS231R.description: This course examines the policy-making process in Canada at the municipal, provincial, and federal levels to give students a sense of the players and their roles. It examines how policy agendas are set and the role of power and interest groups in the policy-making process. It also examines the various types of policies and the implementation process.

SDS240R.title: SDS240R - Art and Society
SDS240R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS240R.description: Social issues and themes explored through the arts. Topics include art and social change, war and peace, propaganda, art of conscience, and the response of artists to poverty, hunger and catastrophic events. Specific applications include art as cross-cultural awareness and art as therapy.

SDS242R.title: SDS242R - Religious Diversity and Social Development
SDS242R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS242R.description: Religious traditions and beliefs contribute both positively and negatively to social development. This course explores the interrelationship of religious diversity, multiculturalism, and attitudes towards social issues.

SDS245R.title: SDS245R - Dying and Bereavement
SDS245R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS245R.description: This course explores end-of-life topics including epidemiology of dying and death in Canada; sociocultural aspects of palliative and end-of-life care; and individual, survivor, and care provider experiences. Students will perform critical analysis of concepts related to dying and death; reflect and expand on personal perspectives of dying and death; and build awareness of dying, death, and grief from the professional, patient, and family/caregiver perspectives.

SDS250R.title: SDS250R - Social Statistics
SDS250R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS250R.description: In this introductory level statistics course students will learn when and how to apply basic principles in the collection, manipulation, presentation, and analysis of numerical social science data. Students will build capacity to be informed consumers of quantitative and hypothesis testing information in social science research.

SDS251R.title: SDS251R - Social Research
SDS251R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS251R.description: This course provides students with a fundamental grounding in social science research. Students will examine various conceptual and practical approaches to planning research and learn to apply both qualitative and quantitative methods to investigating social science research questions.

SDS260R.title: SDS260R - Ecology, Society, and Justice: Social Development and the Environment
SDS260R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS260R.description: This course introduces theory and concepts of social ecology, an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the interrelationship of social and environmental well-being. Students critically examine the implications of environment and environmentalism for human society, as well as explore ideas for community action and social institutions that reflect a social-ecological ethic.

SDS310R.title: SDS310R - Disability and Society
SDS310R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS310R.description: This course examines disability through a social justice lens. Engaging with key texts in critical disability studies, students will explore how dominant ideas of embodiment, difference, expertise, and social value produce (dis)ableism and inequity. Through the social model of disability, it introduces concepts of access, inclusion, disability culture/justice, and universal design.

SDS311R.title: SDS311R - Indigenous Peoples and Canadian Public Policy
SDS311R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS311R.description: Framed within truth, justice, and reconciliation processes underway in Canada, students will examine the historical and ongoing colonial processes and impacts of government policies that target First Nations, Inuit, and Mtis peoples. Students will engage in critical analysis of government policy as a cause of (and response to) social, political, and economic problems experienced by Indigenous peoples in Canada.

SDS312R.title: SDS312R - Homelessness and Public Policy
SDS312R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS312R.description: Students will explore the root causes of the multifaceted problem of housing insecurity, examine its impact on individuals and society, and deconstruct the programs and policies for addressing it. Through a combination of theoretical exploration, case studies, and real-life examples, students will gain a deeper understanding of the challenges faced by unhoused people and the systemic factors that contribute to their status.

SDS322R.title: SDS322R - Community Engagement and Social Development
SDS322R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS322R.description: This course highlights the importance of community engagement for individual, community, and societal well-being and introduces theory and methods related to social inclusion and participation in community. Through case examples and hands-on experience, this course explores approaches to research and professional practice designed to stimulate social development through community engagement.

SDS331R.title: SDS331R - Social Inequality, Social Justice, and Social Action
SDS331R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS331R.description: In this course students explore the relationship between structural power and social inequality through engagement with historic and contemporary social justice movements. Students will critically analyze economic, social, and cultural factors that perpetuate inequality and develop tools to amplify the voices of marginalized communities and seek meaningful social change.

SDS345R.title: SDS345R - Self-Development and Identity Formation: A Sociocultural Perspective
SDS345R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS345R.description: This course examines interdisciplinary approaches (sociological, developmental, psychological, critical, sociocultural perspectives) to identity formation, development, and maintenance. Relevant theories, literature, and research will showcase diverse approaches to understanding social and cultural factors that impact identity formation.

SDS350R.title: SDS350R - Adult Life Crises and Events
SDS350R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS350R.description: A study of normal events occurring during the adult years, why they happen, and how we cope with them. Relying on research, popular literature, and life experiences, students examine social change, the future, adult development and adjustment.

SDS351R.title: SDS351R - Qualitative Research for Social Change
SDS351R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS351R.description: Engaging in histories, stories, language, and media, this course examines how qualitative research can support movements for social change. Students will learn how to conduct research and evaluations through a humanizing approach and have opportunities to participate in diverse research environments while reflecting on their positionalities and identities as researchers.

SDS353R.title: SDS353R - The Evolution of Family Law in Canadian Society
SDS353R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS353R.description: This course examines the evolution of family law in Indigenous, francophone, anglophone, and other communities in Canada. Taking an interdisciplinary approach, the course not only explores the demographic, economic, social, and political contexts in which family law developed but also assesses its significance for Canadian society.

SDS354R.title: SDS354R - Values and Contemporary Families
SDS354R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS354R.description: An exploration of how religious, economic, political, and other social institutions shape values in our society, and what impact society's changing values are having upon families.

SDS355R.title: SDS355R - Resilience and Social Support
SDS355R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS355R.description: This course is a survey of resilience and social support grounded in interdisciplinary study. Students explore how factors such as gender, age, culture, physical and mental health, personality, cognition, severity, and social/interpersonal systems of support affect stress, coping, and resilience.

SDS357R.title: SDS357R - Family Violence
SDS357R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS357R.description: An application of the principles and models of medical, psychogenic, and sociogenic adjustment to an understanding of family violence. The treatment of victims of family violence, the prevention of such violence and social policies affecting family welfare are considered.

SDS358R.title: SDS358R - Child Maltreatment: Identification and Prevention
SDS358R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS358R.description: The objectives of this course are to provide an understanding of the dimensions and causes of child maltreatment, to develop skills identifying cases of this social problem, and to explore current methods of management and treatment of persons involved in child maltreatment situations.

SDS367R.title: SDS367R - Aging and Social Development
SDS367R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS367R.description: This course examines aging from the perspective of human and social development. On individual, group, family, community, and systemic levels, it analyzes interventions for enhancing the well-being of the elderly, emphasizing the roles of social justice and civic engagement in Canadian society.

SDS370R.title: SDS370R - International Learning Experience
SDS370R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS370R.description: This course examines sociocultural realities of a country other than Canada through on site experience and academic study.

SDS375R.title: SDS375R - Studies in Interdisciplinary Social Science
SDS375R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS375R.description: This course will deal with selected topics in interdisciplinary social science. Subjects will be dependent upon the research and/or instructional interests of faculty.

SDS388R.title: SDS388R - Globalization and Social Development
SDS388R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS388R.description: This course explores the rise of globalization; its impact on economics, politics, society, and culture; and its implications for national development and social policies.

SDS398R.title: SDS398R - Independent Study
SDS398R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS398R.description: Interdisciplinary focus in greater depth than is available in other courses, on a selected area of concern to the student. Available to individuals or small groups of third- or fourth-year Social Development Studies students and arranged with one of the program's faculty members.

SDS399R.title: SDS399R - Independent Study
SDS399R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS399R.description: Interdisciplinary focus in greater depth than is available in other courses, on a selected area of concern to the student. Available to individuals or small groups of third- or fourth-year Social Development Studies students and arranged with one of the program's faculty members.

SDS400R.title: SDS400R - Comparative Social Policy
SDS400R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS400R.description: In this course students are introduced to key issues involved in comparative social policy research and develop their analytical skills in systematic comparison. Students will explore the implications of globalization and climate change for social policy development; consider the impact of transnational policy making bodies; and learn how comparative approaches can be used to critique, improve, and reimagine social policy for a just and sustainable future.

SDS405R.title: SDS405R - Cosmopolitanism and Social Development
SDS405R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS405R.description: What does it mean to be a "citizen of the world"? Cosmopolitanism is a social and political philosophy that views all human beings as members of a moral, political, relational, or cultural community. By exploring the philosophy of cosmopolitanism and its implications for social development, students will come to appreciate the complexity and diversity of the current world across intellectual, health, economic, social, cultural, and political factors.

SDS410R.title: SDS410R - Queer and Trans Studies
SDS410R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS410R.description: Centering 2SLGBTQ+ cultural and political contributions, this course examines the ways in which sexualities, bodies, relationships, and identities have been regulated and transformed. Students will analyze how ideas about gender and sexuality structure the contemporary social context, make historical connections, and apply core concepts from queer and trans studies.

SDS411R.title: SDS411R - Decolonization and Social Action
SDS411R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS411R.description: Drawing on theories of decolonization, students explore the relationships between Indigenous and non-Indigenous peoples within, against, and beyond settler colonialism. Students consider and apply the concepts of decolonization, resurgence, unsettling, and reconciliation within today's social and political context.

SDS415R.title: SDS415R - Gender Relations within Educational Institutions
SDS415R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS415R.description: This course focuses on gender in education as both an analytical category and a teaching/learning tool. The course introduces students to the study of gender as it intersects with class, race, sexuality, and disability, by focusing on pedagogy, curriculum, and identity development. Students will develop an understanding of intersectional gender oppression and an awareness of research, policy, and practices for gender justice in education.

SDS420R.title: SDS420R - Critical Encounter with Human Nature
SDS420R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS420R.description: This course explores issues fundamental to human nature and related theoretical explanations. The approach is interdisciplinary and intercultural/interreligious. Through various assignments, students will gain an understanding of their own perspectives on human nature, the questions of human "being" that those raise, and the purpose of human existence.

SDS421R.title: SDS421R - (Re)framing Indigenous-Settler Relations
SDS421R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS421R.description: Interactions between Indigenous and Settler peoples are influenced by historical and contemporary stories told about each other. Students will experience diverse ways of knowing by examining the ideologies, knowledge, beliefs, values, and assumptions behind these stories, within the context of Canada's current Truth & Reconciliation process.

SDS425R.title: SDS425R - Educational Equity in Canada
SDS425R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS425R.description: This course examines the social foundations of education (traditionally philosophy, sociology, and history of education, but also cultural and equity studies). Through an interdisciplinary framework, this course considers the roles that schooling systems, teachers, and students play in both reproducing and challenging social inequities and injustices. Students will critique education processes that reproduce and challenge social inequality through analysis of literature and policy and dialogue about contemporary issues and practices.

SDS435R.title: SDS435R - Restorative Approaches to Education
SDS435R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS435R.description: This course aims to develop understandings and approaches to restorative justice in education through dialogue, communication, and relational pedagogy. Students examine the current state of schools and communities engaging with restorative justice for children and youth, and learn how to explore transformative approaches for promoting equity and inclusion.

SDS440R.title: SDS440R - Approaches to Well-Being
SDS440R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS440R.description: From an interdisciplinary perspective, students will critically examine the concept of living well, reflect on the conditions of their own well-being, and develop strategies to promote well-being in individuals, families, and communities. Specific topics may include the mind-body connection, healthy relationships, work-life balance, spirituality, community engagement, and healthy aging.

SDS441R.title: SDS441R - Popular Culture and Social Change in the Radical Imagination
SDS441R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS441R.description: This course examines the role of popular culture in movements for social and political change. Students will explore both historical contributions and contemporary realities where popular culture becomes a site that fosters the radical imagination.

SDS445R.title: SDS445R - Pedagogies of Democratic Education
SDS445R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS445R.description: Engaging pedagogies for democratic education is a central goal of public and para-public organizations, particularly schools. Yet such democratic engagement is understood differently based on intersecting identities. Students develop their skills for democratic discourse through experiential education and learn how to critically examine democratic education, including civic knowledge, values, and action.

SDS449R.title: SDS449R - Prejudice and Discrimination
SDS449R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS449R.description: This course takes an interdisciplinary approach in examining causes of, impacts of, and ways to overcome stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination. Students will analyze the experience and behaviour of both the target and the purveyor of discrimination from individual, interpersonal, and structural perspectives, and develop anti-oppressive practices.

SDS450R.title: SDS450R - Senior Seminar in Special Topics
SDS450R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS450R.description: Senior seminars may include weekly readings, individual and/or group projects, class presentations and discussions, research proposals, essay/literature reviews, assignments, midterms, and final exams. Consult departmental listings for topics and prerequisites for the current year.

SDS451R.title: SDS451R - Research with Communities
SDS451R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS451R.description: This seminar emphasizes community relationships and applied learning in its pedagogy and practice using social justice informed research methods. Focusing on collaboration, communication, project facilitation, and problem solving, students will engage in practice-based learning in a community setting that addresses real-world issues.

SDS490R.title: SDS490R - Special Studies
SDS490R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS490R.description: An independent, in-depth study, based on empirical research and/or extensive reading from multiple disciplines on a contemporary social issue under the direction of individual instructors in social development studies. Available to individuals or small groups of Social Development Studies majors and arranged with one of the faculty members from the plan. The project must be approved by the academic supervisor of the course prior to registration.

SDS495R.title: SDS495R - Research Apprenticeship
SDS495R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS495R.description: This course invites students to work with a professor on the latter's research project. During this unpaid apprenticeship (six to eight hours per week throughout the term), students will do agreed-upon tasks to help them acquire skills and gain understanding of the research process and of the discipline itself. The faculty member and the student will determine the exact duties together. A document outlining these duties must be approved by the Social Development Studies chair and kept on file. Paid or volunteer positions outside this course are not eligible for credit.

SDS496R.title: SDS496R - Applied Apprenticeship in Social Development Studies
SDS496R.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS496R.description: This course provides third- and fourth-year Social Development Studies students with an opportunity for an unpaid apprenticeship in an applied setting. The course consists of two components. The apprenticeship component typically requires a commitment of 6-8 hours per week for 10 weeks. The seminar component requires students to meet bi-weekly, as a group, with the course co-ordinator to set learning goals, to discuss rewards and challenges arising from their apprenticeship (including how culture, education, and other aspects of identity may impact their placement) and to present their apprenticeship experiences and outcomes.

SDS499A.title: SDS499A - Senior Honours Essay/Thesis
SDS499A.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS499A.description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, students focus on an area of social development studies and either complete an essay involving in-depth literature research and analysis or complete a scholarly report on their own study involving literature review, research design, data collection, and analysis.

SDS499B.title: SDS499B - Senior Honours Essay/Thesis
SDS499B.subject: Social Development Studies (SDS)
SDS499B.description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, students focus on an area of social development studies and either complete an essay involving in-depth literature research and analysis or complete a scholarly report on their own study involving literature review, research design, data collection, and analysis.

SWREN411R.title: SWREN411R - Indigenous Knowledges and Decolonizing Social Work Practice with Indigenous Peoples
SWREN411R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN411R.description: This integrative practice course examines colonial impacts on social work policies and service delivery that adversely affect Indigenous Peoples in Canada. Indigenous knowledges and the importance of cultural practices for healing central to shifting colonial notions of 'best interest' are examined. Engagement in a reflexive stance encourages an inward gaze and analysis of the structural powers that work to sustain political, economic, environmental, and social injustices, as well as the identification of and actions towards decolonizing social work practices, relationships, and allyship with Indigenous Peoples.

SWREN414R.title: SWREN414R - Interviewing and Assessment in Social Work Practice
SWREN414R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN414R.description: This social work methods course explores the theory and skills of generalist social work practice, with particular attention to interviewing, communication, and assessment skills used with individuals, families, organizations, and communities. Emphasis is placed on developing capacity for "critical reflection" on the social work practitioner's professional and personal self.

SWREN422R.title: SWREN422R - Macro Practice: Critical Considerations of Community Organization
SWREN422R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN422R.description: The course examines and compares the strengths, limitations, differential uses, and interconnections of the range of skills needed for community organization, social planning, and social policy practice. Practical applications such as conference planning, proposal writing and fund raising will be explored.

SWREN423R.title: SWREN423R - Social Work Knowledge and Skills for Diverse Group Work Practice
SWREN423R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN423R.description: The aim of this course is to develop student's knowledge of different approaches to social group work practice, and the ways in which specialized knowledge of client's life conditions, life circumstances, and significant life events informs social work practice with groups within a generalist framework. Emphasis is placed upon conceptualizing and analyzing group-work skills and the capacity for self-directed practice with groups directed towards increasing the resiliency of the group as a whole and the resiliency of individual group members. A salient goal is the use of democratic means so that group process in all social work groups reflects a vision of social justice.

SWREN424R.title: SWREN424R - Social Work and Organizations
SWREN424R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN424R.description: In this course, students will apply critical and anti-oppressive theories to examine how organizations shape social work practice. Students will investigate the relations between social workers, service users, agency colleagues, and other institutions in particular practice settings, and how these are influenced by policies, mandates, forms, and other institutional texts. Key concepts will include diversity, inclusion, anti-racism, decolonization, and institutional (in)justice.

SWREN431R.title: SWREN431R - Practitioner Research in Social Work: Intersectional Considerations
SWREN431R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN431R.description: This course examines contemporary fields of practice. Attention is given to historical developments, service delivery systems, and practices. Research activities help develop a critical understanding of how social experience impacts the ways that people with diverse experiences access and encounter some of the major fields of practice.

SWREN434R.title: SWREN434R - Selected Theories for Social Work Practice: Analysis and Application
SWREN434R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN434R.description: In this course, students are provided an overview of selected theories that guide a generalist-eclectic approach to social work practice. It offers students the opportunity to engage in the critical analysis and application of contemporary theories by integrating theory with social work values and principles. The course emphasizes the critical use of theory to understanding, critiquing, and transforming the social work profession.

SWREN441R.title: SWREN441R - Practicum 1
SWREN441R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN441R.description: This first practicum phase helps students understand the general structure and functioning of the helping network and the place of agency-based community settings in it. Simultaneously, the students begin to integrate interviewing and assessment skills to formulate an intervention plan with sensitivity to the diversity of the setting. A bi-weekly seminar runs concurrently with the practicum.

SWREN442R.title: SWREN442R - Practicum 2
SWREN442R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN442R.description: The second practicum phase develops students' intervention skills. Opportunity is given to enhance social work practice skills specific to particular client populations within the context of diversity, and to develop awareness of one's professional self in relation to social work practice within the agency context. A bi-weekly seminar runs concurrently with the practicum.

SWREN443R.title: SWREN443R - Practicum 3
SWREN443R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN443R.description: The third practicum phase helps students demonstrate understanding of, and ability to use, a range of interventions within the context of diversity. Professional identification and the integration of theory with practice are emphasized. A bi-weekly seminar runs concurrently with the practicum.

SWREN470R.title: SWREN470R - Mental Health Landscapes, Concepts, and Practice Approaches
SWREN470R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN470R.description: This course uses an intersectional lens to critically explore social work practice and distress, mental health, and substance use. Students explore, understand, and apply different knowledges, worldviews, and intervention frameworks related to distress, mental health, and substance use, including national policy frameworks and Indigenous approaches to wellness and healing. Key topics in mental health and substance use are considered including trauma and trauma-informed services, harm reduction, and recovery-oriented principles and services as they are relevant to social work practice. Students are introduced to community- and peer-based approaches to distress and recovery.

SWREN471R.title: SWREN471R - Social Work with Older Adults: Critical Issues and Future Trends
SWREN471R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN471R.description: Focusing on social work practice, policy and research, the course examines issues of aging such as health, economic changes, role transition, family dynamics and losses. The course also looks at implications of societal issues and the influence of recent Canadian research in the field of aging. Current innovative and traditional programs will be examined for their relevance for future work with populations of older adults.

SWREN472R.title: SWREN472R - International Context of Practice: An Experiential Learning Opportunity
SWREN472R.subject: Social Work (Bachelor of Social Work) (SWREN)
SWREN472R.description: This course provides a framework for understanding a developing country through a comparative study with Canada.
